page.title: 02BOW HISTORY
page.content: {Bow}is situated half way between Crediton and Okehampton.The village name comes from Bow Bridge over the River Yeo-the word means that the bridge is built of round stones not flat ones used for clapper bridges.The village comprises one main street,the sites having been occupied since the time of{WILLIAM THE CONQUEROR.}Many houses are named after former occupants such as Tozers and Godfreys. The villagers were employed in agriculture and the Tannery which for 150 years,until 1887,was a thriving industry.Two mounds by the road near Bow Bridge were erected over the bodies of men who died in a skirmish between Parliamentary Forces and the Royal troops in 1643.On 29th July 1644 Charles I left Crediton and slept in Bow for a night before going on to Okehampton.
